title: 112_hr2882
content: The Act may be cited as the "National September 11 Memorial and Museum Act of 2011". Congress finds that on September 11, 2001, the largest terrorist attack in the United States occurred, resulting in the deaths of nearly 3,000 people at the World Trade Center, the Pentagon, and in Shanksville, Pennsylvania. The National September 11 Memorial and Museum Foundation has been dedicated to raising funds for and overseeing the design, construction, and operation of the Memorial and Museum at the World Trade Center site since 2003. Millions of people from all over the world have visited Ground Zero to pay their respects. The Memorial at the World Trade Center site honors those who died in the 9/11 attacks and recognizes survivors and those who showed compassion. It also aims to educate future generations about the events of that day. The September 11 Memorial at the World Trade Center site is a public-private partnership scheduled to open on the 10th anniversary of the attacks. It is projected to be one of the most visited venues in the United States, reflecting the impact of the terrorist attacks. Congress has authorized operating funds for memorials and museums of national significance. The purpose of this Act is to promote the Memorial's goals, including honoring the victims of the 1993 and 2001 terrorist attacks, respecting the sacred site, and recognizing the survivors and heroes. Nearly 60% of funds come from private donations, while 40% come from public sources. The Act aims to honor the victims of the 1993 and 2001 terrorist attacks, respect the sacred site, recognize survivors and heroes, educate about the history of September 11, and support other memorials in the US. The Act defines key terms such as Board, Memorial, and Secretary. The Board refers to the Board of Directors of the National September 11 Memorial and Museum, the Memorial is located at the World Trade Center in New York City, and the Secretary refers to the Secretary of the Interior. The Secretary may accept donation of title to the Memorial from the Board, subject to mutually agreed terms and conditions, approval by relevant authorities, and satisfactory title form. The Secretary can also provide technical and financial assistance to the Board for Memorial operation, consulting with other government officials if needed. The Secretary of Education, Homeland Security, Housing and Urban Development, and General Services provide assistance to the Board for Memorial operation. Authorization of appropriations up to $20,000,000 annually for the implementation of the Act, with a requirement for matching funds from non-Federal sources.
